columns.text: In this case, the problem requires us to calculate the accounting break-even and the cash break-even of various scenarios.

For the first requirements, we need to compute the accounting break-even point, but before that, let's first briefly define what an accounting break-even is.

**Accounting break-even** is the point where the difference in an entity's sales and expenses resulted in zero profits.

The accounting break-even point is calculated with the following equation:

$$\text{Accounting break-even point}=\left(\dfrac{\text{Fixed cost}+\text{Depreciation}}{\text{Selling price}-\text{Variable cost}}\right)$$

For the next requirements, we need to calculate the cash break-even point, but before that, let's first briefly explain what a cash break-even is.

**Cash break-even** is the point where the sales level is sufficient to provide a positive business cash flow. 

It is computed using this equation:

$$\text{Cash break-even point}=\left(\dfrac{\text{Fixed cost}}{\text{Selling price}-\text{Variable cost}}\right)$$

Let us now proceed with the computation of the cash break-even point in various scenarios.

1. Cash break-even when the variable cost is $2,135 per unit.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Cash break-even point} &=\left(\dfrac{\text{Fixed cost}}{\text{Selling price}-\text{Variable cost}}\right)\
\\[10pt]
&=\left(\dfrac{{\$8,100,000}}{{\$2,980}-{\$2,135}}\right)
\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{{\$8,100,000}}{{\$845}}
\\[10pt]
&= \boxed{9,586\text{ units}}
\end{aligned}$$

**As presented above, the cash break-even point is 9,586 units when the variable cost is $2,135 per unit.**

2. Cash break-even if the variable cost is $41 per unit.
$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Cash break-even point} &=\left(\dfrac{\text{Fixed cost}}{\text{Selling price}-\text{Variable cost}}\right)\
\\[10pt]
&=\left(\dfrac{{\$185,000}}{{\$46}-{\$41}}\right)
\\[10pt]
&=\left(\dfrac{{\$185,000}}{{\$5}}\right)
\\[10pt]
&= \boxed{37,000\text{ units}}
\end{aligned}$$

**As seen above, the cash break-even point is 37,000 units when the variable cost is $41 per unit.**

3. Cash break-even if the variable cost is $3 per unit.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Cash break-even point} &=\left(\dfrac{\text{Fixed cost}}{\text{Selling price}-\text{Variable cost}}\right)\
\\[10pt]
&=\left(\dfrac{{\$2,770}}{{\$9}-{\$3}}\right)
\\[10pt]
&=\left(\dfrac{{\$2,770}}{{\$6}}\right)
\\[10pt]
&= \boxed{462\text{ units}}
\end{aligned}$$

**As seen above, the cash break-even point is 462 units when the variable cost is $3 per unit.**
